title: stratcols
text: Stratigraphic columns constructed using as_stratcol: optional argument L_unit can used associate length unit bed thicknesses. optional argument base specifies position base lowest bed. is_stratcol can used test object valid stratigraphic column: Bed thicknesses can extracted using bed_thickness: can extract (unique) facies names follows: functionality includes
code: thickness = runif(10) #bed thicknesses facies = rep(c(1,2), 5) # facies codes  s = as_stratcol(thickness = thickness,                 facies = facies) is_stratcol(s) #> [1] TRUE bed_thickness(s) #>  [1] 0.080750138 0.834333037 0.600760886 0.157208442 0.007399441 0.466393497 #>  [7] 0.497777389 0.289767245 0.732881987 0.772521511 facies_names(s) #>  [1] 1 2 1 2 1 2 1 2 1 2 unique_facies_names(s) #> [1] 1 2 no_beds(s) # number of beds #> [1] 10 no_facies(s) # number of distinct facies. #> [1] 2  total_thickness(s) # total thickness of column #> [1] 4.439794  get_base(s) # lowest bed boundary #> [1] 0 get_L_unit(s) # length unit of beds #> NULL  facies_repetitions(s) # do at least two successive beds have identical facies? #> [1] FALSE merge_beds(s, mode = "identical facies") # merge successive beds with identical facies #> Stratigraphic column

title: Structure and classes of the stratcols package
text: S3 class stratcol represents simple stratigraphic column. Structurally, lists 3 fields: bdry : numeric vector, boundary beds units stratigraphic column fa : vector, facies names beds L_unit : NULL string, length unit bed thickness fields following constraints: fa must exactly one element less bdry. bdry must least 2 elements.

text: vignette describes quantify stratigraphic order using metrics defined Burgess (2016).

title: Quantifying stratigraphic order
text: First, define stratigraphic column:
code: s = as_stratcol(thickness = runif(90), # random bed thicknesses                 facies = rep(c(1,2,3), 30)) # repeat facies 1, 2 and 3  plot(s)

title: Quantifying stratigraphic order
text: can estimate transition matrix facies using estimate markov order metric (MOM) using
code: m = transition_matrix(s) m #>    from #> to  1 2 3 #>   1 0 0 1 #>   2 1 0 0 #>   3 0 1 0 #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "fa_tran_mat_p" get_mom(m) #> [1] 1

title: Quantifying stratigraphic order
text: run order metrics (ROM) can estimated using put value context, randomize section estimate distribution rom values red line indicates extreme rom value stratigraphic column s compared expected distribution rom values based random reordering beds.
code: rom_observed = get_rom(s) rom_observed #> [1] 1.41573 n = 10000 rom_vals = rep(NA, n) for (i in seq_len(n)){   randomized_column = shuffle_col(s)   rom_vals[i] = get_rom(randomized_column) }  hist(rom_vals,      main = "distribution of ROM values") lines(x = rep(rom_observed, 2), y = c(0,n), col = "red")

title: Quantifying stratigraphic order
text: estimate markov order metrics, data preparation needed make sure assumptions encoding stratigraphic column met. Let’s start defining example stratigraphic column:
code: set.seed(1) s = as_stratcol(thickness = runif(30), fa = rep(c(1,2,3), 10)) # uniform bed thickness, ordered facies s = shuffle_col(s, allow_rep = TRUE) # randomize order of beds, allowing  for repetitions plot(s)

what: Check for successive beds with identical facies
title: Quantifying stratigraphic order
text: MOM examines transitions facies, ignores beds identical facies. meet criterion, first need merge beds identical facies: ### Rearrange facies names next assumption facies enumerated using integers based order appearance column. can using order_facies_names: ### estimating transition matrix Now can estimate facies transition matrix: Note merged beds identical facies, entries diagonal 0 - facies transition .
code: s_merged = merge_beds(s, mode = "identical facies") plot(s_merged) s_ord_names = order_facies_names(s_merged) plot(s_ord_names) m = transition_matrix(s_ord_names) m #>    from #> to          1         2         3 #>   1 0.0000000 0.8333333 0.1666667 #>   2 0.1428571 0.0000000 0.8571429 #>   3 0.7142857 0.2857143 0.0000000 #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "fa_tran_mat_p"
